text:
(1)
Pierrepont Street, south side, between Pierrepont Place and Hicks Street. A view of the Chinese gardens, and the home of John T. Martin which were razed in late 1898 or 1899. In the right of the view (1929) an art gallery occupies the site, and in the left of the view, the Heights Casino.

June 1898.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
Same, showing a closer view. In the center is a write up about the homes and gardens.

June 1898.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(1)
Pierrepont Street, south side, between Pierrepont Place and Hicks Street. A view of the Chinese gardens, and the home of John T. Martin which were razed in late 1898 or 1899. In the right of the view (1929) an art gallery occupies the site, and in the left of the view, the Heights Casino.

June 1898.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
Same, showing a closer view. In the center is a write up about the homes and gardens.

June 1898.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

1. Pierrepont Place, at the S.W. corner of Pierrepont Street, showing the Henry E. Pierrepont residence. 1922.

2. The same, showing also a portion of No. 2 Pierrepont Place. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

1. Pierrepont Place, at the S.W. corner of Pierrepont Street, showing the Henry E. Pierrepont residence. 1922.

2. The same, showing also a portion of No. 2 Pierrepont Place. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

6 Pierrepont Street, south side, east of Pierrepont Place, showing the home of John F. James, a banker, who in 1861 became a partner in the real estate firm of Wyckoff and Little, whose offices are at No. 189 Montague Street.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

1-3 Pierrepont Place, west side, south from Pierrepont to Montague Streets. The pedestrians bridge in the background, crosses Montague Street, which at this point, slopes down to the East River. Also seen is 2-10 Montague Terrace, west side, south from Montague to Remsen Streets. (Montague Terrace, is really a continuation of Pierrepont Place).

June 1926.

Brown Brothers.

Pierrepont Place, east side, south from Pierrepont Street.

June 11, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

1. Pierrepont Place, east side, from Pierrepont Street; in the background, to Montague Street in the foreground. The bridge is a passenger crossing Over Montague Street, which street starts down at the East River. April 7, 1932.

2. The same; showing the west side of Pierrepont Place. April 7, 1932.

3. The same, as seen from Montague Street which here slopes downwards to the East River. The upper level is used solely by pedestrians. April 7, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

2. The same; showing the west side of Pierrepont Place. April 7, 1932.

3. The same, as seen from Montague Street which here slopes downwards to the East River. The upper level is used solely by pedestrians. April 7, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
